item.title: How to Compare APR and Fees Across New Jersey Lenders
item.description:
Rate vs APR: The NJ Borrower Mistake

Many NJ borrowers focus on the interest rate and ignore APR. That’s a mistake. APR includes lender fees, points, and closing costs, making it the true cost of borrowing.

Example: Two NJ Lenders

Lender A

  • Rate: 6.65%
  • Origination: 0.5% ($4,000 on $800K loan)
  • Total fees: $5,500
  • APR: 6.74%

Lender B

  • Rate: 6.50% (sounds better)
  • Origination: 1.5% ($12,000)
  • Total fees: $14,500
  • APR: 6.86%

Despite the lower rate, Lender B costs more. APR reveals the truth.

item.title: Portfolio Lenders in New Jersey: When You Need Flexibility
item.description:
What Is a Portfolio Lender?

A portfolio lender keeps loans in-house rather than selling them to Fannie Mae or Freddie Mac. This allows manual underwriting and flexibility on DTI, income documentation, and property type—critical in New Jersey where property taxes and jumbo pricing create unique hurdles.

When NJ Borrowers Need Portfolio Lending

1) Jumbo Loans Above $806,550

NJ’s conforming loan limit is $806,550. Any loan above that requires jumbo financing. Portfolio lenders often provide better approval odds for high-balance loans.

item.title: New Jersey Mortgage Lender Types: Credit Unions vs Banks vs National Lenders
item.description:
NJ Lenders Are Not One-Size-Fits-All

New Jersey borrowers face a unique mortgage landscape: high property taxes, frequent jumbo transactions, and diverse county markets. That’s why lender type matters. The right lender depends on your goals—lowest rate, fastest closing, or flexible underwriting.

The Three Core NJ Lender Types

1) Credit Unions

  • Best for: 740+ credit, conventional loans, low fees
  • Advantages: Member pricing 0.125%–0.25% below banks, local service
  • Downsides: Slower turn-times during busy seasons, limited jumbo options
